It's about 2 - 2 1/2 '" across.  I'm wondering if this will cause problems with the radiation tattooos.  Is there anyone else on the boards with a chest tattoo who had rads? Posts.Title: "Elective" tattoos and rads TorchSong TorchSong

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 01:08PM TorchSong wrote: Hi all-- My hair started growing back (well, apikes and fuzz) after my last FEC and has continued to inch its way out...about 1/4 of an inch now, 8 weeks after the last FEC (but three weeks after the last taxotere). So I can see it will grow (if slowly and come in grey and so on) There is progress here!  But what about the rest of my hair? My eyebrows/lashes are thinking about it--little dots and miniature lashes.  But--no underarm hair (not that I miss that much) or leg hair (don't miss tht either) and (this does bother me) no "private"hair. Somehow it's that and the head hair that bother me most.   Question: I may be interviewing for a new job in about a month. They know about my bc and treatments, but how do I minimize the impact of a prectically-bald woman? I want to project an image of a competent, energetic person who can hit the ground running and do wonderful things for them--and I'm worried that my baldness will project the opposite--"oh, the poor cancer patient!" I don't use or have a wig, I usually wear a beret or bucket-style hat. Thoughts/suggestions?
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 10:03AM TorchSong wrote: I had 3X FEC and then 3X Taxotere, and mine began growing about six weeks after the last FEC--so while I was still in treatment, but after the last of the FEC. The T apparently didn't affect my hair growth. it's now (4 weeks after the last T, about 8 weeks after the last FEC) about 3/4 inch, fuzzy and grey/white. It looks like a halo when the light is behind my head! So it may depend on the treatment schedule. My hair is doing pretty well, my fingernails however...well, less said the better! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 09:11AM TorchSong wrote: Hey, Mumayan, I live in Windsor ON and cross the border several times a week... When I had my scans, the hospital gave me a letter saying I had had the scans and what kind of radoactive stuff have been used, etc. I guess since we're a border city they're more familiar with the need for that. Funny thing is, they've never asked me to take off my hat or even looked at me sideways--and I don't look much like my passport photo anymore. In the photo, I have almost shoulder-length hair, glasses, and weigh about 40 pounds more than I do now. No hair, no glasses, thinner--and somehow they can recognise that it's me. lol Now watch, they'll grill me today! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 09:03PM TorchSong wrote: Ack! I've just started losing mine... Day 13 after my first chemo. Drain clogged in the shower, sore scalp, full hairbrush. Yep. Good thing I planned  my Sinead O'Connor party for Friday! I seriously am having a bunch of my friends join me at another friend's salon to clip me short (not really ready for an actual shave, though). I'm getting more nervous about it, but even from just today, I know if I don't I'll be sorry. I have a habit of running my fingers through my hair, and every time I did that today, I had a bunch of hairs between my fingers. Of course you all have been through this already. And there does seem to be an end to the tunnel--eyebrow stubble and peach fuzz, roll on! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2008 10:55AM TorchSong wrote: ChristiC, I hated, hated, hated losig my hair. I cried, I whined, I carried on to everyone. I hadn't felt good about myself for a long time, then in the last few months pre-dx, I had finally begun to feel good about myself nad how I looked (weight loss, hair style, etc.). And then this stupid disease showed up! It was so not fair. Even though I decided to have a party to ease me through it, I was sure I was going to cry the entire time. I made sure that the people I invited were people i would feel OK crying with. But by the time I did the deed (not that one, shaving my head), it actually felt good,. It was a relief--"OK, that's over with, now let's move on to the next step." it's very hard to get through, but you will and you might even find it's easier on the other side than you thought.  Hugs and hugs! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2008 08:21AM TorchSong wrote: Cristl, you might want to try what I did. I sent my partner some digital photos of myself taken at the shaving party, so she had an idea what I looked like before she saw me in reality. That way, she could be totally supportive by the time she saw me--sort of gave her a heads-up. Your bf sounds like he'll be OK...sometimes I think we're harder on ourselves than anyone else is. Hugs to you! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2008 03:27PM TorchSong wrote: I had a party when I clipped mine! I had thought it would be a way to let friends support me--be there, have some fun instead of, "Oh, poor Martha" all the time, Instead it ended up being support for me! We had wine and cheese,  my stylist friend clipped my hair into several different styles so I could see what I might like when it grew (and I loved that he put it that way), and then we had some fun--he shaved my initial on the back of my hair, he gave me a mohawk... I know that wouldn't work for everyone, but it gave me a way to deal with it positively. Also, so much was falling out by then that it was just disgusting...on my keyboard, on my pillow, in my sink drain and even my food! Ick! I was ready for a clip. We ended up shaving it because it was so patchy I looked like I had mange! I do hats...mostly just plain winter ones, althogh a friend crocheted me one. I find the wigs uncomfortable, and I'm not a scarf/turban person, either. I probably have more than I need, as people keep giving them to me--about 12 or so. It does give me a wardrobe, but there are about 3 or 4 that I wear most of the time. I wasn't going to let anyone see me bald, either, but last night I was just too warm, and asked my partner if she would be OK with it if I took my hat off. She said (brilliant answer), "You do what you need to be comfortable, that's more important than anything else." And she thought I was cute!  As others have said, you'll find what works for you! Martha
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 01:35PM TorchSong wrote: On the subject of help.... I'm in a "helping profession" and known in the community, so I have a LOT of people asking how they can help. I started out by saying, "Well, we're not quite sure what kind of help we'll need, but we'll definitely keep you in mind!" But then people would call a week later or email and say, 'So what can we do?" So now I honestly try to think of something a person can do who offers to help.  if they are specific (a ride to treatment, meals, pick up books at the bookstore), and it's something I need, i'll take them up on it. If they're vaguer, I'll give them something general or targeted to what they said they wanted to do ("Food? Well, I've been craving a good mac n cheese, if you 've got a good recipe..."). None of them are anything that has to happen--the important stuff like groceries and rides to treatment and such are already planned out with family--so if the offered events don't happen, it's ok but they are things/help it would be great to have . It sounds like a bit of work for "help," and maybe it is, but I also look at it this way...they want to help, and if I accept it (especially with a specific request), then maybe they'll find they can do it and offer help to someone else on down the road, who needs it even more than I do. And if they decide it's a hassle or I'm too particular, then they've learned (I hope) that they didn't really want to help anyway.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 09:48PM TorchSong wrote: Hi Kristi-- I had my first chemo on the 5th--so I'm about 15 days out. I had the same problem with constipation. I used a laxative for the first time in my life, because I was so uncomfortable and i was worried about hemerrhoids. I used Senekot, one tab, and it worked like a dream. I also found that the one week mark was a turning point--after six or seven days I started feeling better--tired, but not the other stuff. I don't know what you're taking...I'm on FEC, so your results may vary. hugs--we will get through this!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2008 05:18PM TorchSong wrote: Hi Lori--I think several of us are having treatments on Wednesday--I know I am! And so, no big plans for me this year. My mother will be here, but it will be just the two of us, as my partner has to be elsewhere. We're staying flexible--I have a turkey breast, so if I'm feeling up to going out, Mom wants to do that; if I'm not up to going out, but up for cooking and eating we'll have the turkey; if I'm not up for anything, Mom will have it all to herself and I'll just have mashed potatoes and gravy!. My worry is that I will have more of a reaction this time than I did the first time...but we'll see! hugs all around-- Martha

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2008 09:34PM TorchSong wrote: I'm on Day 13 after my first tx (FEC) and the hair is falling like rain! I had already made the decision to cut it very short. I don't think I'll go all the way to a shave, but I'll have to see what it looks like too. I'm actually having a party at a friend's salon (a Sinead O'Connor party, lol). He told me we could start with clipping it short and see what my head shape is like and whether we're down to my grey roots or if I have red tips from my colour! If I decide I want to, he'll shave it on down for me. I've got about three soft hats (chenille) and a couple of fancier ones that my partner bought for me as a "first chemo" present. My favourite is the velvet bucket with the satin rose...
Posts.Title: when did you shave your head? mela4409 goldie0827

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2009 09:40AM TorchSong wrote: Hi all-- I went out Saturday night to the club without hat--my first time hatless (wigless/scrafless too). I was really nervous going in, but after about ten minutes I forgot about it, unless one of my frends commented on it as they arrived. I did get some compliments, and no negative looks or comments. So--on Sunday I didn't wear a hat either (I'm a minister).  Again, people were great with it. So I think I'm done with hats, unless I need one to keep warm!

Posts.Title: Just been told my mum has weeks to live kazzyann TorchSong

Posts.Content: TorchSong wrote: When I was young (10 yo), I had an auto-immune disorder (ITP), which resulted in my having my spleen removed. I've lived without it quite well every since (now 48), including childbirth. In September I was dx with BC (details below), and have just started chemo this week, My onc says that given my good health otherwise, clearly my other organs have picked up the slack from the (missing) spleen. He plans to keep a close eye on my cell counts, of course, as he would for anyone but especially so in my case. I'm wondering if anyone else out there is missing a spleen (for whatever reason) and if you've had any issues or had to do anything differently. I like my onc and trust him, but I just wanted to double check with the knowledge on this board! Thank you! www.caringbridge.org/visit/mar... Dx 9/10/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 1/20 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2008 05:54PM TorchSong wrote: Sassa and Alima, thanks so much--I was beginning to think I was like a unicorn! lol My onc is keeping an eye on me, and stressed that I needed to be extra careful about infections, epsecially from other people--I have a lot of person-to-person contact in my work. I made sure I had all my immunizations up to date (including a flu shot) before I started chemo. I just wasn't sure if there was something else I needed to be aware of... Thanks to you all!
